Hmmm, a lot of ink has been spilled on this question on this list. While I
don't object to your message Alexander, I'd like to motion that we
collectively refrain from reopening this discussion.

Cheers,

Nicholas Lesiecki

-----Original Message-----
From: Alexander Zynevich [mailto:java@...]
Sent: Monday, June 03, 2002 11:54 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] How Junit will test all assert methods, even if one
or more assert methods fails in a TestCase?


I think that there is two kinds of situations (and something in between :-)
:
    1. if some assert fails all subsequent asserts have no sense
    2. all asserts independent, i.e. one failed does not exclude (make
senseless) others.

In the 1st case you should not want to continue test case after one failed.
In the 2nd case your could split you test case onto slmaller test cases, one
assert per test case.


Alexander
----- Original Message -----
From: "Dinesh B Metkari" <dinesh.metkari@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, May 30, 2002 2:58 PM
Subject: [junit] How Junit will test all assert methods, even if one or more
assert methods fails in a TestCase?


> Hi,
> I am having one testcase say:
>
> testInsert(){
>
>       assertTrue();
>       - - - - -
>       assertEqual();
>       - - -
>       assertXYZ()
> }
>
> In above case if first assert method i.e. (assertTrue())  fails, JUNIT
> displays failure  which is occurred at
> first assert only  & It dosent test or checks others assert() Methods.
> My question is:
> How Junit will test all assert methods, even if one or more assert methods
> fails in a TestCase?
>
> Expecting your immediate reply with solution.
>
> Thanks & Regards,
> Dinesh Metkari
>
>
